Escaping the healthcare matrix"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"The secret to great health according to data"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The blueprint to achieve a lifetime of great health is increasingly clear and within our control. But unlocking it requires challenging the orthodoxies currently guiding individuals and institutions."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"The secret to great health may be within our control. In this article, we look at the 23 drivers of health that can be modified to improve our wellbeing."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-12-20T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEach day, millions\u003c/strong\u003e of well-intended healthcare professionals, scientists, and public health officials work diligently to improve our health.[[footnote 1]] Their work has had a profoundly positive impact on global health over the past 50 years and deserves our admiration.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, scrutinizing our mindsets and behaviors against the best-available evidence reveals that the priorities, strategies, and budgets for individuals and of governments, schools, businesses, social institutions, healthcare providers, and employers are, at least implicitly, based on a myriad of half-truths and outdated ideas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo borrow the metaphor from the 1999 eponymous movie classic,[[footnote 2]] we have all been living in a \u0026ldquo;matrix\u0026rdquo; for decades with respect to our health. Life inside the healthcare matrix has its benefits but is incomplete and self-limiting. Once we escape from this matrix, we will realize the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col style=\"list-style-type: decimal;\"\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe suffering we endure to achieve longevity is unacceptable and unnecessary.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMental, social, and spiritual health are as important as physical health and are deeply interconnected.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHealth is mostly about our ability to function, not just about disease and death.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHealth exists on a spectrum: we can\u0026rsquo;t achieve optimal health if we don\u0026rsquo;t define, measure, or strive for it.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMost\u003c/em\u003e drivers of health sit \u003cem\u003eoutside\u003c/em\u003e conventional healthcare systems and are \u003cem\u003emodifiable\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAchieving great health is as much about what we pursue as what we avoid.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePeople are more than patients; they deserve to be empowered with greater health literacy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eHistory suggests that the societal adaptations required to improve health are feasible; every person and institution on Earth has a role to play.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe arguments in this article are globally relevant, although we acknowledge that, in some contexts, the lack of physical or economic security may severely limit the positives and potential of other drivers of health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e1. The suffering we endure to achieve longevity is unacceptable and unnecessary\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDo you accept that you\u0026rsquo;ll probably spend 20 to 30 years in mixed (at best) health and about a decade in awful health\u0026mdash;where you can\u0026rsquo;t remember your children, use the bathroom independently, have sex, walk around the block, or use all five senses?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChildren born today can hope to live 20 years longer than their grandparents born in the 1960s.[[footnote 3]] The number of centenarians has increased nearly 30 times in the same time frame and is becoming a global phenomenon in many middle- and high-income countries.[[footnote 4]] As such, these are terrific developments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut the cost of increased life expectancy has been high. For every extra year of life we have added to our life span, half of that may be in moderate or poor health. This ratio has been roughly constant for decades (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eUp to two-thirds of people experience cognitive impairment around the age of 70.[[footnote 5]] Sixty-nine percent of people will spend an average of three years using long-term care[[footnote 6]]; 2 billion people experience chronic pain,[[footnote 7]] 300 million people are incontinent,[[footnote 8]] 19 million US residents not in a hospital find it difficult to walk a mile,[[footnote 9]] 33 percent of men and 45 percent of women experience sexual dysfunction,[[footnote 10]] 548 million experience symptoms of anxiety or depression,[[footnote 11]] and 33 percent of people worldwide feel lonely.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the healthcare matrix, we have two primary responses to this reality. Some conclude that too many people live too long and have suggested reducing resources invested in older adults.[[footnote 13]] Most implicitly accept that living decades in poor health is lamentable but is an inevitable consequence of having a long life.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we strongly reject both responses. We conclude that the best response is harnessing individual and collective aspirations to fight for strong health until as close to death as possible.\nAs outlined in the McKinsey Health Institute (MHI) report \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/adding-years-to-life-and-life-to-years\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAdding years to life and life to years\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, there is a large body of evidence demonstrating that strong health over an extended period of life is possible. We observe it in select individuals, populations, and societies. It is possible to \u0026ldquo;square the curve\u0026rdquo; of health. Our analysis suggests it\u0026rsquo;s possible to add six years of higher-quality life to every person on the planet over the next decade. That\u0026rsquo;s 45 billion years in total.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e2. Mental, social, and spiritual health are as important as physical health and are deeply interconnected\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHow important is your mental, social, and spiritual health to you? Do you observe linkages between your own mental, physical, social, and spiritual health?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, people and systems focus almost entirely on physical health. In 2020, less than 2 percent of physicians and nurses worldwide were trained in managing mental health problems.[[footnote 14]] More than 90 percent of all healthcare expenditures are spent on treating physical disease or physical symptoms.[[footnote 15]] Most countries don\u0026rsquo;t even attempt to systematically measure mental health, let alone social or spiritual health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we realize that mental, social, and spiritual health are important in and of themselves. In a survey of 19,000 people across 19 countries,[[footnote 16]] around 85 percent of respondents said their mental health is as important to them as their physical health, and their spiritual and social health were also listed by the majority as \u0026ldquo;extremely\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;very important.\u0026rdquo; People share this view across high-, middle-, and low-income countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we recognize that a large and growing body of research is catching up to a few thousand years of philosophical and religious teachings that recognize the linkages among body, mind, and spirit. University of Michigan researchers concluded that people without a strong life purpose were more than twice as likely to die, specifically from cardiovascular disease, than those who did have a strong life purpose.[[footnote 17]] Scientists at the Chonnam National University Medical School in South Korea found a link between anxiety and eyesight problems.[[footnote 18]] Finally, research from National Academies of Sciences found that loneliness among heart failure patients was associated with around a four times increased risk of death and a 68 percent increased risk of hospitalization.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e3. Health is mostly about our ability to function, not just about disease and death\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen someone asks, \u0026ldquo;How\u0026rsquo;s your health?\u0026rdquo; how do you answer?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, health is anchored in the absence or presence of disease, illnesses, and injury. Clinicians, insurers, academics, and governments use \u0026ldquo;mortality\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;morbidity,\u0026rdquo; jargon words for death and disease to guide decision making and resource allocation. We discuss, measure, and pay for healthcare based on whether you \u0026ldquo;have heart failure\u0026rdquo; or don\u0026rsquo;t. We approve, promote, and pay for drugs, devices, and clinical interventions based on their potential impact on disease and death. These are important and useful concepts, but they are also limiting.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe typically[[footnote 20]] don\u0026rsquo;t define or measure functional implications on our life until and unless it is related to a disease or injury. For example, an orthopedic surgeon may measure knee, hip, or shoulder flexion (the ability to bend) after a surgery to gauge the progress of recovery. But knee flexion is not measured or discussed unless a knee problem emerges even though it is necessary for our ability to walk, lift, and exercise correctly[[footnote 21]] and to avoid slips and falls.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, there are no broadly used standards for measuring the holistic physical function (for example, walking, gripping, and balancing) of a disease-free 40-year-old woman or the cognitive function (for example, memory, problem-solving) of a disease-free 50-year-old man. This lack of measurement reveals the lack of focus or concern with function.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we realize that the absence of disease does not, necessarily, imply great health. Similarly, the presence of disease does not, necessarily, impede function, especially if symptoms are well managed. This reality was substantiated by \u003ca href=\"/mhi/our-insights/in-sickness-and-in-health-how-health-is-perceived-around-the-world\"\u003eMHI\u0026rsquo;s 2022 survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in 19 countries\u0026mdash;\u003cem\u003e40 percent\u003c/em\u003e of those reporting a disease perceived their health as \u0026ldquo;good\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;very good.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese respondents recognize that health is mostly about living. Strong health helps us lead meaningful, productive, and satisfying lives. Health is the extent to which we have physical and mental energy, whether we can fully use our senses, and the extent to which we can comfortably engage in meaningful activities. Health is our strength, our memory, our ability to solve problems; it is our ability to cope with the challenges of life, our ability to build and sustain intimacy, and our sense of agency, positivity, and purpose (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHealth is fundamentally about what an individual can do (or not) today and what they are able to do (or not) in the future.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce we escape from the matrix, we realize that we need better, more standard ways to define, measure, and talk about function across all dimensions of health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e4. Health exists on a spectrum: We can\u0026rsquo;t achieve optimal health if we don\u0026rsquo;t define, measure, or strive for it\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf you ask your daughter how she\u0026rsquo;s doing in geometry, would you be satisfied if she responded \u0026ldquo;Great. I didn\u0026rsquo;t fail the last test\u0026rdquo;? How well would a football club perform if it only practiced defense? If you asked your physician, \u0026ldquo;Am I in optimal health?\u0026rdquo; how would they answer?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, health is framed almost exclusively in the negative. Achieving a \u0026ldquo;clean bill of health\u0026rdquo; means that you haven\u0026rsquo;t been diagnosed with a disease or a major risk factor of disease. Patients are categorized based on the level of the problem: a standard \u0026ldquo;acuity table\u0026rdquo; consists of four levels: stable, moderate risk, complex patient, and high-risk patient. The best is \u0026ldquo;stable\u0026rdquo; health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGlobally, we spend more than $8 trillion annually to avoid disease, symptoms, and death, yet there are no commonly accepted words or standards to delineate mediocre from great health.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, the concept of achieving \u0026ldquo;optimal\u0026rdquo; health is relegated to the domain of \u0026ldquo;biohackers,\u0026rdquo; affluent middle-aged people in high-income countries, professional athletes, and celebrities. The implicit assumption is that aspiring to optimal health is a luxury that few can afford metaphorically and literally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we realize that health exists on a spectrum with a negative \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e positive or optimal end. We realize that achieving better-than-mediocre health is feasible in large numbers. Our recent research supports this conclusion. Of the 13,200 people across 19 countries who reported no disease, around 25 percent indicated being in \u0026ldquo;very good\u0026rdquo; health, 55 percent in \u0026ldquo;good\u0026rdquo; health, and 20 percent in \u0026ldquo;fair\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;poor\u0026rdquo; health. This spectrum of responses was similar across high-, middle-, and low-income countries and across age bands. (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we aspire to be more than not sick, not disabled, and not suicidal. We want vitality, centeredness, and resilience. We want our brains to work the best they can. We want to be good at building intimacy. We want to be able to walk, play, carry, and build for as long as possible without discomfort.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we recognize that striving to achieve optimal (over mediocre) health is a highly effective prevention strategy. We \u003cem\u003ealso\u003c/em\u003e recognize that aspiring for optimal health is an effective approach to generate real-time, concurrent benefits to individuals and society. A disease-free person who successfully improves their metabolic health, learns to navigate their emotions, prioritizes sufficient high-quality sleep, and avoids harmful content, substances, and stress is likely to enjoy more energy, build stronger relationships, and enhance personal productivity. They are more likely to be a better colleague at work, a better spouse, a better parent, and a better friend (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch2\u003e5. \u003cem\u003eMost\u003c/em\u003e drivers of health sit \u003cem\u003eoutside\u003c/em\u003e conventional healthcare systems and are \u003cem\u003emodifiable\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eIf changing an aspect of your life within your control decreased the odds of acquiring dementia by 25 percent, would you want to know about it? Would you expect your physician to tell you about it? Would you expect your government, private insurer, or employer to help you achieve it?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, we assume that the primary drivers of an individual\u0026rsquo;s health are genetics, chance, and access to and adoption of conventional healthcare interventions. We define conventional healthcare interventions as a handful of widely adopted public health strategies (for example, vaccines, sanitation, seat belts, and smoking cessation), the timely detection and diagnosis of disease, and access to clinical interventions like pharmaceuticals, surgery, and therapy provided by licensed clinicians. More than 97 percent of health-related public-, private-, and social-sector expenditures in OECD countries are related to delivering conventional healthcare interventions.[[footnote 23]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen we acknowledge the relevance of a handful of nonconventional drivers such as diet, exercise, and substance use, we frequently refer to these drivers with dismissive terms such as \u0026ldquo;lifestyle.\u0026rdquo; Deconstructing that word is revealing: the word \u0026ldquo;life\u0026rdquo; reflects the belief that the extent to which these drivers are optimized (or not) is mostly the purview of the individual and not affected by systems and structures of society (for example, employment, education, food availability, economics, and social context). The word \u0026ldquo;style\u0026rdquo; implies superficiality or inferiority compared to what we consider more legitimate interventions that we label with credibility-enhancing qualifiers like \u0026ldquo;clinical.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, we assume that the evidence for conventional health system interventions is much stronger and more reliable than the evidence for interventions associated with nonconventional drivers.\nOutside the matrix, we recognize that conventional healthcare drivers are critical. Creating more and more equitable access to these resources is just and economically wise. Greater investment to improve conventional interventions offers substantial potential benefits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe \u003cem\u003ealso\u003c/em\u003e recognize that a large and growing body of evidence suggests that at least 19 of the 23 drivers of our health sit outside conventional healthcare systems. Each of these drivers appears to have an independent, direct, material, and causal impact on our health. These drivers include what we put into our bodies, how we spend our time, when and how we move, what our minds and bodies are exposed to, and what we believe about the nature of reality, ourselves, and other people.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Table 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eNote: Drivers of health are complex and nonlinear (eg, J-curves, U-curves), interact with one another and their effects can vary by genetics, traits, randomness, etc. Each driver can be optimized (or un-optimized) based on quantity, type, mix, duration, timing/sequencing and can be a result of both individual choices and structural/environmental influences.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e(We also provide more detail on evidence of these drivers in \u0026ldquo;The healthy 23: Drivers of your health and\u0026nbsp;longevity\u0026rdquo; \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey health institute/our insights/the secret to great health escaping the healthcare matrix/table-1-the-healthy-23-drivers-final.pdf\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.)\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThousands of studies and even more anecdotal evidence highlight that these drivers are often the difference between decades of strong function and decades of poor health and/or premature death. Examples include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMultiple studies demonstrate that exercise alone can deliver between three and five years of extended life and between five and ten years of improved quality of life.[[footnote 24]] Cardio training, strength/resistance training, and high-intensity exercise all appear to be independently valuable and important.[[footnote 25]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eOptimistic/positive people (a learned behavior) are 35 percent less likely to experience a cardiovascular event compared to a pessimist holding other variables constant. Positivity has also been shown to reduce the prevalence and symptoms of depression and anxiety and improve immune-system function.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIncreasing evidence suggests that regular use of saunas at high temperatures decreases the risk of all-cause mortality by as much as 40 percent and the risk of dementia by as much as 66 percent.[[footnote 26]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFasting has shown the ability to reverse type 2 diabetes in large portions of people and reduce the likelihood of cognitive decline. Emerging research is demonstrating that ketogenic diets can help treat serious mental illness.[[footnote 27]] Higher blood glucose levels in nondiabetics is associated with between a 30 percent and 40 percent higher likelihood of cardiovascular and cancer-related death.[[footnote 28]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMultiple studies have found DHA (docosahexaenoic acid) and EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid) supplementation (fish oil) can lower the risk of cognitive decline, especially in people at high risk for Alzheimer\u0026rsquo;s disease.[[footnote 29]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDozens of studies demonstrate that walking reduces chronic pain, strengthens the immune system, and decreases anxiety, sadness, and fatigue.[[footnote 30]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA recent randomly controlled experiment demonstrated that exposure to nature for 60 minutes reduced stress and improved the brain\u0026rsquo;s ability to successfully navigate future stressors.[[footnote 31]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMore than five hours of daily social media use was associated with between a 35 and 50 percent increased risk of depressive symptoms in adolescents.[[footnote 32]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eA recent review of medical literature suggests that human sperm counts have fallen by more than 50 percent around the globe over the past 50 years. While the causes are unknown, the lead research suggests that exposure to man-made chemicals, obesity, sedentariness, and ultraprocessed food may play a role.[[footnote 33]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhat\u0026rsquo;s more, these drivers are \u003cem\u003emodifiable\u003c/em\u003e. They can be improved or weakened based on both individual choices and how systems and structures operate. This is incredibly positive news.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePerhaps for the first time in history, most of us have meaningful agency over our health for most of our lives, regardless of our genetics.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we realize that \u003cem\u003emost\u003c/em\u003e of the distinctions between \u0026ldquo;clinical\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;lifestyle\u0026rdquo; interventions are \u003cem\u003emostly\u003c/em\u003e artificial. Why is a pill or surgery a more legitimate health intervention than calorie restriction, lifting weights, meditating, avoiding particular content, or walking in nature? If it works, it works. If it doesn\u0026rsquo;t, it doesn\u0026rsquo;t.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we recognize that the totality of evidence is already overwhelming that nonconventional, modifiable drivers of health are deeply relevant to our health. A substantial body of research exists that links each of the 23 modifiable drivers of health to either a material improvement in physical, mental, social, and/or spiritual function and/or to longevity. This is true despite the fact that less than 5 percent of modifiable drivers of health are defined consistently (or at all), captured systematically, and made broadly available as data. It is challenging to research what we do not measure well. This is also an important reason why much of the research demonstrates a correlation and does not fully prove causation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we recognize that the evidence around nonconventional drivers is imperfect, and there is a great deal we don\u0026rsquo;t know about how to optimize each. There is much less clarity around mechanisms of causality, the magnitude of impact that each driver has on each dimension of health, appropriate dosing, interaction effects, and how best to personalize. But outside the matrix, we view these gaps in knowledge as creating an imperative to invest dramatically more resources in researching and understanding these drivers, rather than as a rationale to discount them.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[disruptor1up dis1]]\n\u003ch2\u003e6. Achieving great health is as much about what we pursue as what we avoid\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDoes eating with loved ones, spending time on meaningful activities, laughing, walking in the park, building new skills, and/or playing games that cause perspiration sound boring or painful?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt some point while discussing health inside the matrix, someone will mention the quip, \u0026ldquo;You\u0026rsquo;ll live to be a hundred if you give up all the things that make you want to.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe implication is that optimizing health requires sacrifices that are simply not worth it. From a systems perspective, the implication is that humans are so hardwired for \u0026ldquo;unhealthy\u0026rdquo; behaviors that large-scale change is unachievable, especially in the context of a consumer-driven economy oriented toward near-term hedonic enjoyment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we understand that this sentiment is mostly false and highly fatalistic. It overemphasizes the benefits of avoiding what\u0026rsquo;s harmful versus pursuing what\u0026rsquo;s beneficial. It inaccurately pits short-term hedonic benefits against longer-term satisfaction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOptimizing health requires some moderation of select activities, substances, content, food, relationships, etcetera. Valuing moderation itself is associated with strong health. It can be difficult to give up harmful habits, especially when reinforced by systems and culture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut it is \u003cem\u003emore\u003c/em\u003e true that optimizing health requires taking action and pursuing objectives that mostly result in near-term happiness and long-term well-being. A more constructive mindset is to emphasize the many beneficial and intrinsically rewarding aspects of optimizing health. Pursuing favorable actions also has the benefit of \u0026ldquo;crowding out\u0026rdquo; harmful behaviors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, optimizing \u003cem\u003emost\u003c/em\u003e drivers of health is \u003cem\u003emostly\u003c/em\u003e about doing \u003cem\u003emore\u003c/em\u003e of what people enjoy intrinsically so they can continue to do those things \u003cem\u003elonger\u003c/em\u003e. This is terrific news. Eating healthy food, including with moderate alcohol, especially with loved ones, is enjoyable. Building stronger, healthier relationships is rewarding. Spending time in \u0026ldquo;flow\u0026rdquo; at work is rewarding. Sleeping well is rejuvenating. Most people enjoy some form of sport or physical activity as long as it is not labeled \u0026ldquo;exercise.\u0026rdquo; Most people want to learn to cope with challenges more effectively. Most of the actions required to optimize longer-term health also have near-term physiological benefits like improved mood, energy, and performance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e7. People are more than patients; they deserve to be empowered with greater health literacy\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWho is the best steward of your health? What actions can you take to improve your own health or the health of people in your circle of influence?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, human health is primarily the responsibility of health ministers, healthcare providers, and the life sciences industry. Private payers, employers, and social institutions play important roles in select countries. Individuals are recognized as relevant but are thought of and treated as \u0026ldquo;patients.\u0026rdquo; Merriam-Webster\u0026rsquo;s dictionary defines a patient as \u0026ldquo;an individual awaiting or under medical care and treatment.\u0026rdquo; Patients are passively \u0026ldquo;awaiting\u0026rdquo; and, by definition, engaged only when treatment is warranted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost people do not possess strong health literacy. In Europe, the most recent large-scale survey estimated that less than 20 percent of respondents self-assessed that they possessed excellent health literacy.[[footnote 34]] During the COVID-19 pandemic, 50 percent of adults in Europe reported not having the required competencies to take care of their health.[[footnote 35]] Moreover, few countries have made improving health literacy a priority.[[footnote 36]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOutside the matrix, we conclude that in an increasingly complex world where day-to-day living is the primary determinant of health, individuals must be the long-term stewards of their own health. Recognizing the primacy of individuals does not in any way undermine the role of institutions, systems, and structures. It acknowledges the reality that in most cases there is no other person or institution with a commensurate level of information, incentive, or influence as an individual themselves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecognizing this reality should lead to more substantial investment and doing more to improve the health literacy of the world\u0026rsquo;s population. Functioning well in modern societies requires acquiring a minimum health literacy threshold, but also knowledge across a range of disciplines including economics (for example, checking accounts, credit cards, mortgages), construction (for example, basic home repair), and technology (for example, computer usage). How can an individual steward their metabolic health without basic knowledge of energy balance, macro nutrients, and insulin? Health-literate individuals are better equipped to optimize their own health including making day-to-day trade-offs. They are more demanding customers of health-related products, services, and treatments. And they are more likely to demand and/or drive adaptations in public policy, employment, and other systems that positively affect their health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e8. History suggests that the societal adaptations required to improve health are feasible; every person and institution on Earth has a role to play\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDid you ever think it possible that many billions of people would wear uncomfortable masks in public?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInside the matrix, the skeptic reminds us that achieving large-scale behavior change is difficult. They remind us that many aspects of modern life and consumer-demand-driven economies seem to be at odds with many actions required to optimize health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce we escape the matrix, however, we realize that humans are incredibly adaptable. We realize that large-scale behavior change is not only possible, it is normative over time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo highlight just a few examples of large-scale changes in human behavior with a positive effect on human health, consider the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn 1920, 1 percent of US homes had electricity and indoor plumbing. Indoor plumbing led to massive decreases in deaths from diarrhea, enteritis, and typhoid fever.[[footnote 37]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ePrevalence of smoking among men has declined 50 percent or more in Japan, many European countries, and the United States over the past 50 years.[[footnote 38]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMask wearing in public went from globally rare to common in several Asian countries in the 1990s, then to a near global norm during the COVID-19 pandemic.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSeat belt usage increased from 14 percent in 1983 to 90 percent in 2016.[[footnote 39]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eNutritional fortification and supplementation have benefited billions of people.[[footnote 40]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWorkplace injury, illness, and death remain unacceptably high but have fallen dramatically over the past one hundred years.[[footnote 41]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe note that most of the favorable changes in human behavior typically involve a virtuous cycle of institutional and individual action. To this end, we believe every institution on Earth has a role to play in improving health literacy and adapting strategies, policies, and resources to help optimize health.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce they escape from the healthcare matrix \u0026hellip;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvery government ministry,\u003c/em\u003e including finance, education, agriculture, environmental, transportation, housing, energy, telecommunications, and commerce considers how to use its resources to positively affect drivers of health while developing strategies to improve health literacy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvery business\u003c/em\u003e realizes it is in the business of health. They realize that most (if not all) of the products and services they offer do (or could) affect one of the modifiable drivers of health. They recognize that helping people optimize their health could be an attractive economic opportunity and positively affect society.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvery employer\u003c/em\u003e recognizes the profound impact that an employee\u0026rsquo;s experience has on their health. The extent to which an employee finds meaning in their work, their physical experience, the nature of their work, their interpersonal interactions, the way in which they are developed (or not), the degree and stability of compensation and benefits, and an employer\u0026rsquo;s policies and programming materially affect \u003cem\u003eevery\u003c/em\u003e modifiable driver of health. Employers realize that adapting to improve the health of their employees is both just and economically attractive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvery conventional healthcare stakeholder\u003c/em\u003e embraces the need to modernize and adapt. They continue to innovate and improve the ability to detect, treat, and cure disease with conventional interventions. They \u003cem\u003ealso\u003c/em\u003e embrace that they are in the best position to define, measure, and promote an understanding of health that is holistic and anchored in function. They commit to defining and promoting optimal health and to better understanding and applying insights from nonconventional drivers of health. They fundamentally recognize that empowering individuals must be the foundation of our health systems. As such, they lead by example in improving health literacy and supporting individuals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAuthors\u0026rsquo; note: We close by reaffirming our gratitude for the millions of people dedicated to improving our health. You literally save our lives every day.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe invite you and every other reader to venture outside the healthcare matrix, to aspire to great health and act more decisively. It may be uncomfortable, but we believe dramatic improvements in human health are possible if we act. And w\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003ee want to hear from you! The world inside the matrix is not unpleasant: it\u0026rsquo;s relatively safe, internally consistent, but obstructs the insights into and path toward a potentially better authentic life.
